flask_scheema.api.decorators module¶

flask_scheema.api.decorators.auth_required(roles: bool | List[str]) → Callable[source]¶

A decorator to check if the user is authenticated and has the required roles.

Parameters:

roles (Union[bool, List[str]]) –

  • False: No authentication required.

  • True: Only authentication is checked.

  • List of roles: Authentication and role-based access are checked.

Returns:

The decorated function.

Return type:

Callable

Raises:

HTTPException – If the user is not authenticated or does not have the required roles.

flask_scheema.api.decorators.check_roles(user, roles: List[str])[source]¶

Check if the user has the required roles.

Parameters:

  • user (User) – The user object.

  • roles (List[str]) – List of roles required to access the route.

Returns:

True if the user has the required roles, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

flask_scheema.api.decorators.check_serialise_method_and_return(result: Dict, schema: AutoScheema, model_columns: List, schema_columns: List)[source]¶

Checks to see if the columns that have been output match the columns in the model and schema, if not its likely a custom serialise method has been used, and we should return the result as is (list of dicts) rather than serialising in marshmallow.

Parameters:

  • result (Dict) – The result dictionary

  • schema (Schema) – The schema to get the fields from

  • model_columns (List) – The model columns

  • schema_columns (List) – The schema columns

Returns:

A dictionary of all the fields

Return type:

Dict

flask_scheema.api.decorators.fields(model_schema: Type[AutoScheema], many: bool = False) → Callable[source]¶

A decorator to specify which fields to return in the response.

Parameters:

  • model_schema – Marshmallow schema for the model.

  • many – Indicate whether to return multiple objects or a single object.

Returns:

Decorator function.

Examples

/addresses?fields=id,account

/addresses?fields=id,account,date_created

flask_scheema.api.decorators.handle_error(e: Any, status_code)[source]¶

Handle errors and return a standardised response.

Parameters:

  • e (Exception) – The exception.

  • status_code (int) – The status code to return.

Returns:

an error response

Return type:

response

flask_scheema.api.decorators.handle_many(output_schema: Type[AutoScheema]) → Callable[source]¶

A decorator to handle multiple records from a route.

Parameters:

output_schema (Schema) – The Marshmallow schema to serialize the output.

Returns:

The decorated function.

Return type:

Callable

flask_scheema.api.decorators.handle_one(output_schema: Type[AutoScheema], input_schema: Type[AutoScheema] | None = None) → Callable[source]¶

Decorator to handle input and output using Marshmallow schemas for single record operations.

Parameters:

  • output_schema (Schema, optional) – The Marshmallow schema to serialize output.

  • input_schema (Schema, optional) – The Marshmallow schema to validate and deserialize input.

Returns:

The decorated function.

Return type:

Callable

Examples

@app.route(‘/addresses/<int:address_id>’, methods=[‘GET’]) @authrequired([]) @handle_one(AddressSchema, AddressSchema)

def get_address(address_id: int, deserialized_data: Dict[str, Any]) -> Dict[str, Any]:

return Address.query.get(address_id)

flask_scheema.api.responses module¶

class flask_scheema.api.responses.CustomResponse(value: List | Any | None = None, count: int | None = 1, error: List | Dict | Any | None = None, status_code: int | None = 200, next_url: str | None = None, previous_url: str | None = None, many: bool | None = False)[source]¶

Bases: object

Custom response class to be used for serializing output.

flask_scheema.api.responses.create_response(value: Any | None = None, status: int = 200, error: str | Dict | None = None, count: int | None = 1, next_url: str | None = None, previous_url: str | None = None) → Response[source]¶

Create a standardised response.

Parameters:

  • value (Optional) – The value to be returned.

  • status (Optional) – HTTP status code.

  • error (Optional) – Error message.

  • count (Optional) – Number of objects returned.

  • next_url (Optional) – URL for the next page of results.

  • previous_url (Optional) – URL for the previous page of results.

Returns:

A standardised response dictionary.

flask_scheema.api.responses.deserialize_data(input_schema: Type[Schema], data: Any) → Dict[str, Any] | Tuple[Dict[str, Any], int][source]¶

Utility function to deserialize data using a given Marshmallow schema.

Parameters:

  • input_schema (Type[Schema]) – The Marshmallow schema to be used for deserialization.

  • data (Any) – The data to be deserialized.

Returns:

The deserialized data if successful, or a tuple containing errors and a status code if there’s an error.

Return type:

Union[Dict[str, Any], Tuple[Dict[str, Any], int]]

flask_scheema.api.responses.filter_keys(model, schema: Type[Schema], data_dict_list: List[Dict])[source]¶
flask_scheema.api.responses.serialize_output(output_schema: Type[Schema], data: Any) → CustomResponse[source]¶

Utility function to serialize output using a given Marshmallow schema.

Parameters:

  • output_schema (Type[Schema]) – The Marshmallow schema to be used for serialization.

  • data (Any) – The data to be serialized.

Returns:

The serialized data if successful, or a tuple containing errors and a status code if there’s an error.

Return type:

Union[Dict[str, Any], tuple]

flask_scheema.api.utils module¶

flask_scheema.api.utils.endpoint_namer(model: DeclarativeBase | None = None, input_schema: Schema | None = None, output_schema: Schema | None = None)[source]¶

Gets the endpoint name for the model, based on the model name.

Parameters:

  • model (DeclarativeBase) – The model to get the endpoint name for.

  • input_schema (Schema) – The input schema for the model.

  • output_schema (Schema) – The output schema for the model.

Returns:

The endpoint name.

Return type:

str

flask_scheema.api.utils.get_description(kwargs)[source]¶

Gets the description for the route, first checking the model’s Meta class for a description attribute, then if not found, returning a default description based on the method.

kwargs:

Keyword arguments that include the model and the method type (GET, POST, etc.)

Returns:

The description string for the route

Return type:

str

flask_scheema.api.utils.get_models_relationships(model: Callable)[source]¶

Checks the model for relations and returns a list of relations, if any. If the relation is a many to many, it will not log the association table as a relation but the other side of the relationship.

Parameters:

model (Callable) – The model to check for relations

Returns:

A list of relations

Return type:

list

flask_scheema.api.utils.get_primary_keys(model)[source]¶

Gets the primary key columns for the model.

Parameters:

model (Callable) – The model to get the primary key columns for.

Returns:

The primary key column.

Return type:

Column

flask_scheema.api.utils.get_tag_group(kwargs: dict) → str[source]¶

Gets the x-tagGroup for the route, first checking the model’s Meta class for a tag_group attribute, It is pulled from the group meta-attribute of the model.

Parameters:

kwargs – yword arguments that include the model and the method type (GET, POST, etc.)

Returns:

The description string for the route

Return type:

str

flask_scheema.api.utils.setup_route_function(service, method, multiple=False, many_to_many_model: Callable | None = None, get_field: str | None = None)[source]¶

Sets up the route function for the api, based on the method. Returns a function that can be used as a route.

Parameters:

  • service (CrudService) – The crud service for the model.

  • method (str) – The http method.

  • multiple (bool) – Whether the route is for multiple records or not.

  • many_to_many_model (Callable) – The model to use in the join.

  • get_field (str) – The field to get the record by.

Returns:

The route function.

Return type:

function
